title: scanorama
description: Use Scanorama to integrate different experiments.

output_compression.description: Type: `string`, example: `gzip`, choices: ``gzip`, `lzf``. The compression format to be used on the output h5mu object
output_compression.help_text: Type: `string`, example: `gzip`, choices: ``gzip`, `lzf``. The compression format to be used on the output h5mu object.

obs_batch.description: Type: `string`, default: `batch`. Column name discriminating between your batches
obs_batch.help_text: Type: `string`, default: `batch`. Column name discriminating between your batches.

obsm_input.description: Type: `string`, default: `X_pca`. Basis obsm slot to run scanorama on
obsm_input.help_text: Type: `string`, default: `X_pca`. Basis obsm slot to run scanorama on.

obsm_output.description: Type: `string`, default: `X_scanorama`. The name of the field in adata
obsm_output.help_text: Type: `string`, default: `X_scanorama`. The name of the field in adata.obsm where the integrated embeddings will be stored after running this function. Defaults to X_scanorama.

knn.description: Type: `integer`, default: `20`. Number of nearest neighbors to use for matching
knn.help_text: Type: `integer`, default: `20`. Number of nearest neighbors to use for matching.

batch_size.description: Type: `integer`, default: `5000`. The batch size used in the alignment vector computation
batch_size.help_text: Type: `integer`, default: `5000`. The batch size used in the alignment vector computation. Useful when integrating very large (>100k samples) datasets. Set to large value that runs within available memory.

sigma.description: Type: `double`, default: `15`. Correction smoothing parameter on Gaussian kernel
sigma.help_text: Type: `double`, default: `15`. Correction smoothing parameter on Gaussian kernel.

approx.description: Type: `boolean`, default: `true`. Use approximate nearest neighbors with Python annoy; greatly speeds up matching runtime
approx.help_text: Type: `boolean`, default: `true`. Use approximate nearest neighbors with Python annoy; greatly speeds up matching runtime.

alpha.description: Type: `double`, default: `0.1`. Alignment score minimum cutoff
alpha.help_text: Type: `double`, default: `0.1`. Alignment score minimum cutoff

nextflow input-output arguments.title: Nextflow input-output arguments
nextflow input-output arguments.description: Input/output parameters for Nextflow itself. Please note that both publishDir and publish_dir are supported but at least one has to be configured.

publish_dir.description: Type: `string`, required, example: `output/`. Path to an output directory
publish_dir.help_text: Type: `string`, required, example: `output/`. Path to an output directory.

param_list.description: Type: `string`, example: `my_params.yaml`. Allows inputting multiple parameter sets to initialise a Nextflow channel
param_list.help_text:
Type: `string`, example: `my_params.yaml`. Allows inputting multiple parameter sets to initialise a Nextflow channel. A `param_list` can either be a list of maps, a csv file, a json file, a yaml file, or simply a yaml blob.

* A list of maps (as-is) where the keys of each map corresponds to the arguments of the pipeline. Example: in a `nextflow.config` file: `param_list: [ ['id': 'foo', 'input': 'foo.txt'], ['id': 'bar', 'input': 'bar.txt'] ]`.
* A csv file should have column names which correspond to the different arguments of this pipeline. Example: `--param_list data.csv` with columns `id,input`.
* A json or a yaml file should be a list of maps, each of which has keys corresponding to the arguments of the pipeline. Example: `--param_list data.json` with contents `[ {'id': 'foo', 'input': 'foo.txt'}, {'id': 'bar', 'input': 'bar.txt'} ]`.
* A yaml blob can also be passed directly as a string. Example: `--param_list "[ {'id': 'foo', 'input': 'foo.txt'}, {'id': 'bar', 'input': 'bar.txt'} ]"`.

When passing a csv, json or yaml file, relative path names are relativized to the location of the parameter file. No relativation is performed when `param_list` is a list of maps (as-is) or a yaml blob.
